title: Grade 11
subject: Alternative Content Standards - English Language Arts (2017-)

document.title: ESSENTIAL ELEMENTS FOR GRADE 11: ENGLISH LANGUAGE ARTS

27A0457C4EF44644A62417ADD9749B2B.description:
Use digital media
strategically (e.g., textual,
graphical, audio, visual, and
interactive elements) in
presentations to support
understanding and add interest.

DCF771D7D0B14728AC4338E59CDF05B3.description:
Write answers to
research questions by selecting
relevant information from
multiple resources.

4F0475109FB54EB1AA8547DDDBEB279D.description:
Conduct
research projects to answer
questions posed by self and
others using multiple sources of
information.

37A26133DD254BEF94DDB36115B273AD.description:
Use technology,
including the Internet, to
produce, publish and update an
individual or shared writing
project.

26137D6BBA5D4A7094CE6297EFF58BF0.description:
The student can
identify a word that describes an
experience or event while preparing
to write/communicate about it.

56E46086FF554EE59C5B525E264D44C4.description:
The student can
identify words that describe an
experience or event while
preparing to write/communicate
about it.

070B58BC24164E9992F7D17EEF8C5FC7.description:
The student can
identify/use descriptive words to
create a vivid picture while
preparing to write/communicate
about an experience or event.

08EAEC8BE7224848B62355393FD52BCE.description:
Write about
events or personal experiences:
Use descriptive words and phrases
to convey a vivid picture of
experiences, events, setting, or
characters.

5F510A4D08F2427BB978C73F1A849BDC.description:
The student can
select a fact or detail related to a
given topic.

25B5B3CE8AC2419CBCFBFF359C4F5C38.description:
The student can
select facts or details that relate to
a given topic.

91B9787646C240FFAE3AE99949E86215.description:
The student can
identify/list/organize facts, details,
or quotes to support a given topic.

67EE466ED75847F7B2828B4A44FA2324.description:
Write to share
information supported by
details: Develop the topic with
relevant facts, details, or quotes.

A70793D2F96148FC9743C57F24948350.description: Students can investigate topics and present information.

55497357D9464F95ADEDAE3A3655DB62.description:
Use general
academic and domain-specific
words and phrases across
contexts.

3E42BDF3FCF041E79D7D9F621F410CF2.description:
The student can
identify the correct use of language
to communicate effectively with
familiar people (e.g., sharing
information, responding to
greetings, being polite, and making
simple requests, etc.)

8BDDD956AB4F4C36BECE7474706F70DB.description:
The student can use
language to communicate
effectively with a variety of
audiences and for different
purposes (e.g., asking questions,
sharing information, responding to
greetings, using polite expressions,
using appropriate body language).

608BCBE977704C02A2C5D0A27AD70DDB.description:
The student can use
complex language, including
compound sentences, to
communicate effectively with peers
and adults (e.g., asking and
answering questions, sharing
information, clarifying statements,
making requests, etc.)

01EFE929C127463B89AEC998A637C684.description:
Use language to
achieve desired outcomes when
communicating. A. Vary sentence
structure using a variety of simple
and compound sentence structures.

2E26B58AE1534546A3A7B6D9ED35BFE4.description:
Demonstrate
Standard English grammar and
usage when communicating: Use
digital, electronic, and other
resources and tools to improve uses
of language as needed.

FB50FDAEA32E40E0A4F93984A30473A9.description:
The student can
identify/use the correct noun or
action verb when given a picture
prompt.

3ED74837E1C744709832D341E290BC51.description:
The student can
identify/use singular/plural nouns,
verb tense and personal pronouns
when writing or speaking.

44F90D91C342459497E9634EEA3F4842.description:
The student can
identify/use correct conventions of
Standard English when
communicating through writing or
speaking.

0BB767DBC8FE48DBAE5A63BD9458B7F2.description:
Demonstrate
Standard English grammar and
usage when communicating: Use
conventions of Standard English
when needed.

7B5A145FAEB6481BB79BF5250937D82D.description:
Adapt
communication to a variety of
contexts and tasks using
complete sentences when
indicated or appropriate.

B16D808E16C04F469775522DDE2EC9AF.description:
Present an
argument on a topic using an
organization appropriate to the
purpose, audience, and task.

90977A939F0A43E49DB4173DD1422B67.description:
The student can
select one or more details from
information presented orally or
through other media.

4728BA64372349A7B64E6120751E7ADD.description:
The student can
identify the claim/point a speaker
makes.

0DE7B63900054BE3921F1272A1B95E8A.description:
The student can
identify a claim/reasoning that
enhance(s) a speaker’s argument on
a topic.

97B6C461E54248B795208C552A25C2B6.description:
Determine
whether the claims and
reasoning enhance the speaker’s
argument on a topic.

0B6096EFB1D44D9DBE7DA6AD2646D597.description:
Determine the
credibility and accuracy of
information presented across
diverse media or formats.

63225DE21EBF48D8BC6032EF9B955AB3.description:
Engage in
collaborative discussions. A.
Prepare for discussions by collecting
information on the topic. B. Work
with peers to set rules and goals for
discussions. C. Ask and answer
questions to verify or clarify own
ideas and understandings during a
discussion. D. Respond to
agreements and disagreements in a
discussion.

694A3137107C40BA96ECA6B6EA4DEBFE.description: Students can communicate for a range of purposes and audiences.

3389EEC4E6FE49DAB60F913161962310.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of conventions of
Standard English: Spell most
single-syllable words correctly and
apply knowledge of word chunks in
spelling longer words.

CECF17CE4EB44A19BDAC77B255A7EDD5.description:
The student can
differentiate if a sentence is a
statement or a question.

F7D67105FEC34C8D8A9CFA72BB42674F.description:
The student can
identify a sentence that uses the
correct capitalization and/or
ending punctuation.

E32791DA8CFE4BDEB4747B0D00E2C45B.description:
The student can
identify a grammatically correct
sentence that uses correct
capitalization, very basic internal
punctuation, and ending
punctuation.

3BC9EDA95DD24F4FBBC6ACF4C070D814.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of conventions of
Standard English: Demonstrate
conventions of Standard English
including capitalization, ending
punctuation, and spelling when
writing.

E70924E35DE94E4F9CAFD2348EC6D8B8.description:
Write routinely
over extended time frames (time
for research, reflection, and
revision) for a range of tasks,
purposes, and audiences.

3E5EDCF05D7D4D4EBDCCD07993A4C957.description:
Cite evidence
from literary or informational
texts. A. Apply Grades 11-12
Essential Elements for Reading
Standards to literature (e.g.,
“Compare and contrast elements of
American literature to other literary
works, self, or one’s world.
[Compare themes, topics, locations,
context, and point of view].”). B.
Apply Grades 11-12 Essential
Elements for Reading Standards to
informational texts (e.g., “Compare
and contrast reasoning and
arguments used in one's work with
those used in seminal U.S. texts.”).

B09CCA37E86C4060A6CE9C890EE7C0D5.description:
Develop and
strengthen writing as needed by
planning, revising, editing, and
rewriting.

CF5B6F07A1484FBAA980A6CE53C4E761.description:
Produce writing
that is appropriate to a
particular task, purpose, and
audience.

FF3AC18895F346398CE24ABC2A119EC5.description:
Write
about events or personal
experiences. C. Organize the
events in the narrative using
temporal words to signal order and
add cohesion. E. Provide a closing.

C25FAD45F42D4188B0FDE0B0A1EED308.description:
Write about
events or personal experiences:
Write a narrative about a problem,
situation, or observation including at
least one character, details, and
clearly sequenced events.

EBD7C632FA204EEC88AA1FA503D8EDF1.description:
The student can
provide one or more details while
preparing to write/communicate
about a personal experience,
problem, or situation.

F96F670949E24821B975F9065F5F6BCB.description:
The student can
correctly sequence two or more
events while preparing to
write/communicate about a
personal experience, problem, or
situation.

EB97BF42AFC642FA9D2042E4E767747F.description:
The student can
write/draw/dictate about a real-life
problem, situation, or observation
that includes supporting details and
sequenced events.

D15A5E5D1A6C4AC2B76D83A299F57074.description:
Write to share
information supported by
details: A. Introduce a topic clearly
and write an informative or
explanatory text that conveys ideas,
concepts, and information including
visual, tactual, or multimedia
information as appropriate. B. See
**Claim 4. C. Use complete, simple
sentences, as well as compound and
other complex sentences as
appropriate. D. Use domain specific
vocabulary when writing claims
related to a topic of study or text. F.
Provide a closing or concluding
statement.

8E392BEA075A4779906D4A49B97D0370.description:
Write arguments
to support claims. A. Write an
argument to support a claim that
results from studying a topic or
reading a text. B. Support claims
with reasons and evidence drawn
from text.

383CA1C52CF14FDABCD15A4CBF618CCE.description: Students can produce writing for a range of purposes and audiences.

2A0D769840604DC9920267E0872E587A.description:
The student can
identify the correct meaning of
words that have multiple meanings.

CD65EDEC0AF640A98A5CB3E09C1D2F3E.description:
The student can
identify the correct meaning of
words that have multiple
meanings.

1B953CC9FFBC4225A14C85244AF403E8.description:
The student can
identify the meaning of literal or
non-literal/figurative words or
phrases when presented in the
context of narrative or informational
text, including (but not limited to)
multiple-meaning words and
common figures of speech.

3F7277BE129E4B4A9CF59FF32D9D3595.description:
Demonstrate
understanding of word
relationships and use: Interpret
simple figures of speech
encountered while reading or
listening.

3ECA52E099AF4587A65120E49CAF8F79.description:
Demonstrate
knowledge of word meanings:
Consult reference materials
(dictionaries, online vocabulary
supports) to clarify the meaning of
unfamiliar words encountered when
reading.

337DCFFC649745328FEA26E82BCF659B.description:
Demonstrate
knowledge of word meanings:
Identify and use root words and the
words that result when affixes are
added or removed.

486613A5A17F433E8EDA449FE95E7E3C.description:
The student can use
cues to recognize words that may
or may not be familiar, when paired
with pictures.

AD631A77E4E84DDC97EEF8CC06408190.description:
The student can
use context clues to determine the
meaning of words that may or may
not be familiar.

E8D540582BD842FEAFFD492A1C343F87.description:
The student can use
context as a clue to determine word
meaning.

208AD0A196814376AC38A37C6B479E73.description:
Demonstrate
knowledge of word meanings:
Use context to determine the
meaning of unknown words.

629D52C60D4F470A8C838B90A3B19231.description:
Demonstrate
understanding while actively
reading or listening to literary
non-fiction.

3AD1D3E22B4348D581C1C993329FF4F6.description:
Compare and
contrast arguments made by
two different texts on the same
topic.

ECDAD6DFB1614A27B303CAE422E4DDA9.description:
The student can
indicate own opinion (agreement or
disagreement) about the topic of a
short informational text.

04BF490FC2D042CCB953372F1C43E252.description:
The student can
identify a claim made by the author
of a short informational text or
identify one detail that supports
the claim.

C3E2EBA761BD408CBBD05A930D8AD58F.description:
The student can
identify a claim or reason that
enhances the author’s argument in
an informational text.

FC69AA65B3AC4CB88A87E925DC70738D.description:
Determine
whether the claims or reasoning
enhance the author’s argument
in an informational text.

3A9AB1FC77D64C229B9DE4A1AE1258B7.description:
Analyze
information presented in
different media on related topics
to answer questions or solve
problems.

A42C05C52A08451DA65669646656D463.description:
The student can
identify a word/phrase that
describes the author’s
meaning/point of view.

CA14206BA7284E7B91AA023EDD7B1553.description:
The student can
identify a word/phrase that
describes the author’s
meaning/point of view.

6D3DE47D51A34CF7A83A1A3A94EC1ED0.description:
The student can
identify/describe the author’s
intended meaning/point of view and
discuss how it relates to one’s own
point of view.

25E939C540324B3A98AB4E6BC61C8C8E.description:
Determine
author’s point of view and
compare and contrast it with
own point of view.

6D01D07655374C77A58CAB3195551A55.description:
Determine
whether the structure of a text
enhances an author’s claim.

E747A76289F94193804EC1664C763323.description:
Determine how
words or phrases in a text,
including words with multiple
meanings and figurative
language, impacts the meaning
of the text.

9BFB9616EFCC4F59A07DF54D40A34971.description:
The student can
identify an event that occurred or
an individual’s action in a short
informational text.

9A007E4E1B1647C29C3ACD5BF18C12FE.description:
The student can
identify one example that shows
change in an individual, idea, or
event over the course of a short
informational text.

DACBDD17E8ED40C4B04B07458D8BFCFE.description:
The student can
determine one or more ways in
which an individual, idea, or event
changed over the course of an
informational text.

2EC01C3901A44245827810B9CF81CA0C.description:
Determine how
individuals, ideas, or events
change over the course of the
text.

E757728270664DD18C24C19517CAD684.description:
The student can
identify the main idea of a short
informational text.

C1205016C8034D3EB843B44B5578F480.description:
The student can
identify the main idea of a short
informational text, or identify one
detail that supports the main idea
(when the main idea is provided).

45196808EEE3439E9934B60AE89409DB.description:
The student can
identify the main idea of an
informational text and one detail to
support it.

DE1B5BD0BD484C5BB19E837855F2349F.description:
Determine the
central idea of a text; recount
the text.

96990774E16149BAA5EF2DC514F95527.description:
The student can use
details (pictures) to answer
concrete who, what, where, or
when questions about short
informational text.

2E4A7BECC8FB4DF18CCC3109614B6B1C.description:
The student can use
concrete details to answer simple
questions and make predictions
about short informational text.

20CDFC5445AB46108523EF36BECE94EA.description:
The student can use
explicit and implicit information
from an informational text to
answer questions about the text.

67B08D52FD2D42D98CE23DBACDBB454A.description:
Analyze a text to
determine its meaning and cite
textual evidence to support
explicit and implicit
understanding.

23808AFD034C4F39A70219B6CD44CA0E.description:
Demonstrate
understanding while actively
engaged in reading or listening
to stories, dramas, and poems.

129B2633CFD6421BBCF41F15E367C3C2.description:
Demonstrate
explicit understanding of
recounted versions of
foundational works of American
literature.

26C10FB1A35E4E98889B5D27017DE649.description:
Compare two or
more interpretations (e.g.,
recorded or live production of a
play or recorded novel or
poetry) of a story, drama, or
poem.

973889F9C0DE47E48BB1D6DA738F41C5.description:
Determine the
point of view when there is a
difference between the author’s
actual language and intended
meaning.

87ACE32E862F41D2ADD1C15D6C215844.description:
Determine how
the author’s choice of where to
end the story contributes to the
meaning.

22D8D79C76324BEB93B50B7D9ED5C512.description:
Determine how
words or phrases in a text,
including words with multiple
meanings and figurative
language, impact the meaning.

951D01FADA2C44CEA29C40DEC8666825.description:
The student can
identify an event that occurred or a
character’s action in a short
narrative text.

9F4D82C3B86548E7BE75B799AA7DD139.description:
The student can
identify one example that shows
change in a character, setting, or
event from a short narrative text.

A9D4AF0C502644539063607817EB612F.description:
The student can
determine one or more ways in
which a character, setting, and/or
event changed or developed over
the course of a narrative text.

95E60BD007654C02BE9A1D0969CA9878.description:
Determine how
characters, the setting or events
change over the course of the
story or drama.

B84C5D1B58C14ED0866E0A124374B4C1.description:
The student can
identify the theme or main idea of a
short narrative text.

7474DBD4CECD488E865927371D801F86.description:
The student can
identify the theme or main idea of a
short narrative text.

32F639EEBA484A529A13F02A1FB6D0F6.description:
The student can
determine how key events in a
narrative text relate to the theme
or main idea and/or help the reader
infer it.

B6B1C7980A9C490897665C9EAC77D1BA.description:
Recount the
main events of the text which
are related to the theme or
central idea.

C2A0933477DD4D328AA3766C04356940.description:
The student can use
details (pictures) to answer
concrete who, what, where, or
when questions about short
narrative text.

5B1DBCA2A77A4D6AB09674FB8FDBA63C.description:
The student can use
details from a narrative text to
answer questions and make
predictions.

274DE090A1914562AAB2D960AEA39C13.description:
The student can use
explicit and implicit information
from a narrative text to answer
questions about the text.

146FB77AD7BC47218306069084DB9131.description:
Analyze a text to
determine its meaning and cite
textual evidence to support
explicit and implicit
understandings.

A06BFA598D414A7D8D0143B81C70B9EE.description: Students can comprehend text in increasingly complex ways.
